conclusion: Understanding the problem involves a symmetric velocity-time graph and finding scenarios for a particle passing through a position three times.
Explanation of a velocity-time graph: x-axis is time, y-axis is velocity, slope gives acceleration, area under curve gives displacement.
Graph is symmetric about t = t0, starts at t = 0 with positive velocity, decreases to zero at t = t0, increases negatively, then increases back to positive velocities.
Graph starts at t = 0 with positive velocity, decreases to zero at t = t0, increases to negative velocity at t = t1, decreases back to zero beyond t1.
Position is determined by the integral of velocity with respect to time.
Considering symmetry and velocity changes, the particle moves in positive direction, stops or changes direction at t0, moves negatively, and then increases back towards zero.
Velocity at time t is equal to velocity at time 2*t0 - t due to symmetry.
Area under the curve from t = 0 to t0 is positive, indicating movement away from starting point.
Area under the curve from t0 to t1 is negative, indicating movement back towards starting point.
Total displacement from t = 0 to t = t1 is zero due to symmetry, meaning the particle ends at the starting position.
Particle passes through the starting position three times, implying it goes away and comes back twice.
